thread.title_full: Adelaide Film Festival: Tanna, Bad Boy Bubby and Spear enthral in different ways

author: Garry Maddox
title: Adelaide Film Festival: Tanna, Bad Boy Bubby and Spear enthral in different ways
text:
Dain and Wawa in Tanna. 
With grass skirts, feathered head-dresses and penis sheaths, the villagers from one of the South Pacific's last traditional tribes were a striking sight as the romance Tanna had its Australian premiere at the Adelaide Film Festival.
Eight cast members who had never seen a movie until they collaborated to make one arrived in the cinema warmly singing, dancing and waving to the audience.
And screening in a tropical atmosphere – the airconditioning was turned off as a courtesy to the scantily clad guests – Tanna proved to be a touching and beautiful insight into an ancient tribal culture. 
Hunter Page-Lochard (centre) as Djarli and Bangarra dancers in Stephen Page's Spear. 
The winner of the Critics Week prize in Venice and opening in cinemas next month, it was devised by longtime documentary directors Bentley Dean and Martin Butler with the villagers of Yakel​, who live by ancient traditions they call kastom​ , on a Vanuatu island.
Advertisement They have created what feels like a richly authentic film about a controversial romance between a young couple from the same tribe, based on real events that took place in the 1980s. And considering none of the cast had acted before, there are some impressive performances, especially by Marie Wawa and Mungau Dain​ as the couple whose love is threatened by tribal conflict.
Tanna is the latest example of a promising new stream in Australian film – filmmakers reaching out into the region to tell collaborative stories in foreign languages, joining The Rocket in Laos, Ruin in Cambodia and Arrows of the Thunder Dragon in Bhutan. 
Bold vision: Nicholas Hope in Bad Boy Bubby. 
There was a full spectrum of experiences in the first four days of director Amanda Duthie's second Adelaide festival. And they were not all as warm in every sense as Tanna. 
Bad Boy Bubby , Rolf de Heer's​ bold 1993 drama about a loner who breaks out of the dingy room he shares with his sexually abusive mother and discovers a disturbing world, had an immersive first-ever screening with binaural sound. 
De Heer's experimental approach to the film included using 32 cinematographers during the shoot and having star Nicholas Hope wear binaural microphones sewn into his wig so the soundtrack resembles what Bubby hears as he emerges into a dark modern world. 
The audience wore headsets for the screening in an old Waterside Workers hall in Port Adelaide, near where the film was shot.
While the film held up well, the experimental sound was most effective as Bubby discovered the modern world, recoiling at the sound of bagpipes, touching lives in a home for the severely disabled and performing like a demented Nick Cave with a punk band. 
The shock value might have receded but the dark comedy behind the film's best-remembered scene – Bubby clingwrapping his cat – still works. 
The Indigenous dance film Spear , which had its world premiere in Toronto last month, was another festival highlight.
As the Tanna cast left the cinema on Sunday, they were greeted by four Aboriginal dancers who were part of the festivities before Stephen Page's feature film directing debut, which led the director to joke that the red carpet felt like a United Nations world Indigenous conference. 
Beautifully shot by Bonnie Elliott,  Spear is an abstract film made up of dance pieces in a warehouse, tunnels, a prison, a rock platform by the ocean and other less specific locations.
While it has no direct narrative, it gradually emerges as a story about an Aboriginal youth, Djali (Hunter Page-Lochard), observing troubling visions of contemporary Aboriginal life before seeming to find his own place in the world.
The ABC is one of its backers but the cinema is the natural home for a haunting experience that features dancers from Page's Bangarra Dance Theatre. The most potent segments feature a ranting, broken figure, Suicide Man (Aaron Pedersen), who describes himself as living between two worlds with a heart that's in neither.
There is also a jokey vaudeville-style scene, watched in apparent horror by Djali, as Indigenous dancers perform to that old song My Boomerang Won't Come Back .
A film that will be compelling for some viewers but a challenge for others was backed by the festival's Hive Fund, which commissions ambitious projects that explore art on screen. It will have special event cinema screenings over summer. 
The festival continues until Sunday, with highlights expected to include the world premiere of Remembering the Man , a documentary about the real couple behind Holding the Man;  a restored version of Storm Boy; and another Australian film telling a story from the region, Tom and Sam McKeith's​ Philippines boxing drama Beast .
The writer was a guest of the festival.
